body_html: I only took a cursory look at it, but I think that the proof of the One-variable linear case from Wikipedia could be generalized to multivariate case. If this is the case, then you can just use the euclidean algorithm to find any solution, and try to adjust dimension indices independently (they could have been negative or large) to make them fall into the desired range.

body: I only took a cursory look at it, but I think that the proof of the [One-variable linear case from Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diophantine_equation#One_equation) could be generalized to multivariate case. If this is the case, then you can just use the euclidean algorithm to find any solution, and try to adjust dimension indices independently (they could have been negative or large) to make them fall into the desired range.
